Andreas Schrader Professor for Ambient Computing University of Lübeck Institute of Telematics Ratzeburger Allee 160 23562 Lübeck Gebäude 64, 3rd Floor, Raum 42 Email: andreas.schrader(at)uni-luebeck.de Phone: +49 451 3101 6420 Head of the Ambient Computing Working group CV Born August 28th, 1964 in Hamburg, Germany 1984 : Abitur (high-school diploma) at the Otto-Hahn-Gymnasium in Geesthacht 1991 : Diplom (equiv. to M.Sc.) in Electronical Engineering 1991 at the University of Siegen 1992 - 1998 : Scientific Employee at the Institute of Programming Languages, University of Siegen 1998 : PhD in Computer Science with Prof. Dr. Wolfgang Merzenich, University of Siegen 1989 - 1999 : Research Staff Member at NEC Europe Ltd., Heidelberg 1999 - 2003 : Senior Research Staff Member and head of Internet Service Gruppe at NEC Europe Ltd., Heidelberg 2003 - 2009 : Professor for Media Technology and Communication Networks, ISNM - International School of New Media, Affiliated Institute of the University of Luebeck June 2007 - Dec. 2011 : Academic Director of the ISNM - International School of New Media Dec. 2010 - Dec 2011 : Manager of the ISNM - International School of New Media July 2017 - Feb. 2024 : Board Speaker of COPICOH - Center for Open Innovation in Connected Health  Since January 2010 : Head of the working group Ambient Computing at the Institute of Telematics at the University of Luebeck Since October 2010 : Professor for Ambient Computing Field of Work Ambient Computing realizes interactive and context-sensitive multimedia applications in ubiquitous and pervasive computing systems. Our many projects focus on different application domains in healthcare and edutainment, e.g. ambient hospital, ambient care, ambient skills labs, ambient gaming, etc. The group develops frameworks for context-aware smart environments supporting dynamic (semi-)automatic composition of interactive hardware and software ensembles. DOI:10.3390/network5030040 Datei: Dateilink Bibtex: @Article{network5030040, AUTHOR = {Kordts, Börge and Brandl, Lea C. and Schrader, Andreas}, TITLE = {Orchestrating and Choreographing Distributed Self-Explaining Ambient Applications}, JOURNAL = {Network}, VOLUME = {5}, YEAR = {2025}, NUMBER = {3}, ARTICLE-NUMBER = {40}, URL = {https://www.mdpi.com/2673-8732/5/3/40}, ISSN = {2673-8732}, ABSTRACT = {The Internet of Things allows us to implement concepts such as Education 4.0 by connecting sensors, actuators, and applications. In the case of direct and explicit connections, we refer to ensembles that can consist of devices and applications. When realizing spatially distributed applications, there are scenarios in which these ensembles must coordinate with each other. In software development, this process is referred to as orchestration or choreography. This paper describes a software framework that provides orchestration or choreography for self-explaining ensembles using predefined rules based on a self-description of all involved components. The framework is capable of generating user instructions or explanations for smart environments that cover interaction details. The approach also forms a basis to provide information about event-based coordination. In a case study, we investigated the technical perception of a coordinated spatial learning game application (an ambient serious game). Most participants perceived the application as cohesive and found it responsive. These results suggest that our framework provides a solid foundation for implementing coordinated applications within smart environments that appear as unified applications.}, DOI = {10.3390/network5030040} } Lea C.
